title: Geometry and Measurement
description: Covers 7.G standards on geometry. Students review and extend circle area and circumference, find the area of composite figures, compute surface area of prisms and pyramids using nets and formulas, calculate volume of prisms and cylinders, and explore cross-sections of three-dimensional figures.
goals: Calculate the area and circumference of circles using A = πr² and C = 2πr (or C = πd)
Find the area of composite figures by decomposing them into rectangles, triangles, and partial circles
Compute the surface area of rectangular prisms, triangular prisms, and pyramids using nets and formulas
Calculate the volume of rectangular prisms and cylinders using V = Bh
Identify and describe cross-sections formed when three-dimensional figures are sliced by a plane
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro → I Do → We Do → You Do
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank
Real-world contexts (gift wrapping, gardening, room layouts, food containers) make geometry concrete and relatable
Formulas introduced alongside visual reasoning — nets for surface area, base-times-height for volume
Students encouraged to draw and label diagrams before computing

scaffold.title: Area and Circumference of Circles
scaffold.content: Circles are everywhere — wheels, clocks, pizzas, sprinklers. Two key measurements describe every circle: the circumference (distance around) and the area (space inside). Both formulas depend on the radius or diameter and the special number π (pi), which is approximately 3.14.
keyPoints: The radius (r) is the distance from the center to any point on the circle. The diameter (d) is twice the radius: d = 2r.
Circumference is the perimeter of a circle: C = 2πr, which is the same as C = πd.
Area of a circle: A = πr². Always use the radius (not the diameter) in this formula.
Use π ≈ 3.14 for calculations unless told otherwise. Exact answers can be left in terms of π.
Common mistake: using the diameter instead of the radius in A = πr². If given a diameter, divide by 2 first.
Units matter: circumference is measured in linear units (cm, ft), area in square units (cm², ft²).

scaffold.title: Area of Composite Figures
scaffold.content: Real-world shapes are rarely perfect rectangles or circles. A room might be L-shaped, a window might be a rectangle topped with a semicircle, or a garden might combine curves and straight edges. To find the area of these composite figures, break them into simpler shapes you already know how to measure.
keyPoints: A composite figure is made of two or more basic shapes combined together.
Strategy: decompose the figure into rectangles, triangles, circles, or semicircles.
If shapes are joined together, ADD their areas.
If a shape has a piece removed (like a hole), SUBTRACT the missing area.
Always draw the figure and label the dimensions of each part before calculating.
Check that your sub-shapes account for the entire figure — no overlaps and no gaps.

scaffold.title: Surface Area of Prisms and Pyramids
scaffold.content: Surface area is the total area of all the faces of a three-dimensional figure. Imagine unfolding a box into a flat pattern (called a net) — the surface area is the area of that entire net. This is useful when you need to know how much material covers the outside of an object, like wrapping paper for a gift or paint for a wall.
keyPoints: A net is a 2D pattern that folds into a 3D shape. Drawing a net helps you see every face.
Rectangular prism: 6 rectangular faces. SA = 2(lw + lh + wh), where l = length, w = width, h = height.
Triangular prism: 2 triangular bases + 3 rectangular faces. Find each area and add them together.
Pyramid: 1 base + triangular lateral faces. The number of lateral faces equals the number of sides on the base.
For pyramids, slant height is the height of each triangular face, not the height of the pyramid itself.
Surface area is always measured in square units (in², cm², m²).

scaffold.title: Volume of Prisms and Cylinders
scaffold.content: Volume measures how much space a three-dimensional figure occupies — or how much it can hold. Think of filling a fish tank with water or packing a shipping box. The key idea is simple: volume equals the area of the base times the height (V = Bh).
keyPoints: Volume formula: V = Bh, where B is the area of the base and h is the height of the prism or cylinder.
Rectangular prism: base is a rectangle, so V = lwh.
Cylinder: base is a circle, so V = πr²h.
Always identify the BASE first — it is the shape that is repeated (stacked) along the height.
Volume is measured in cubic units (in³, cm³, ft³).
1 cm³ = 1 mL, so volume in cubic centimeters tells you capacity in milliliters.

scaffold.title: Cross-Sections of 3D Figures
scaffold.content: When you slice a three-dimensional figure with a flat plane, the shape you see at the cut is called a cross-section. Think of slicing a loaf of bread — each slice shows you a cross-section. Different angles of slicing produce different shapes, even from the same solid.
keyPoints: A cross-section is the 2D shape formed where a plane intersects a 3D figure.
Slicing a rectangular prism parallel to a face produces a rectangle (or square) matching that face.
Slicing a cylinder parallel to its base produces a circle.
Slicing a cylinder perpendicular to its base (straight down through the center) produces a rectangle.
Slicing a pyramid parallel to its base produces a smaller version of the base shape.
The orientation of the cut determines the shape of the cross-section — the same solid can produce different cross-sections.

scaffold.title: Area and Circumference of Circles — Worked Examples

examples.problem: A circular flower bed has a radius of 5 feet. How much soil is needed to fill the bed (find the area)?
examples.solution:
Identify: radius r = 5 ft. We need the area.
Formula: A = πr²
A = 3.14 × 5² = 3.14 × 25 = 78.5 sq ft
You need 78.5 square feet of soil.

examples.problem: A circular running track has a diameter of 50 meters. How far is one lap around the track?
examples.solution:
Identify: diameter d = 50 m. We need the circumference (distance around).
Formula: C = πd
C = 3.14 × 50 = 157 m
One lap around the track is 157 meters.

examples.problem: A sprinkler waters a circular area with a radius of 8 feet. What is the circumference of the watered region?
examples.solution:
Identify: radius r = 8 ft. We need the circumference.
Formula: C = 2πr
C = 2 × 3.14 × 8 = 50.24 ft
The circumference of the watered area is 50.24 feet.

scaffold.title: Area of Composite Figures — Worked Examples

examples.problem: A room is shaped like a 10 ft by 8 ft rectangle, but a 3 ft by 4 ft rectangular closet is built into one corner. What is the floor area of the room (not including the closet)?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Full rectangle area = 10 × 8 = 80 sq ft
Step 2: Closet area to subtract = 3 × 4 = 12 sq ft
Step 3: Room floor area = 80 − 12 = 68 sq ft
The floor area of the room is 68 square feet.

examples.problem: A decorative window is a rectangle 4 ft wide and 5 ft tall, topped with a semicircle that has the same width as the rectangle. Find the total area of the window.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Rectangle area = 4 × 5 = 20 sq ft
Step 2: The semicircle has diameter 4 ft, so radius = 2 ft.
Semicircle area = (1/2)πr² = (1/2)(3.14)(2²) = (1/2)(3.14)(4) = 6.28 sq ft
Step 3: Total area = 20 + 6.28 = 26.28 sq ft
The total area of the window is 26.28 square feet.

scaffold.title: Surface Area of Prisms and Pyramids — Worked Examples

examples.problem: You are wrapping a gift box that measures 12 in long, 8 in wide, and 5 in tall. How much wrapping paper do you need (find the surface area)?
examples.solution:
Formula: SA = 2(lw + lh + wh)
SA = 2(12×8 + 12×5 + 8×5)
SA = 2(96 + 60 + 40)
SA = 2(196) = 392 sq in
You need 392 square inches of wrapping paper.

examples.problem: A tent is shaped like a triangular prism. The triangular base is a right triangle with legs 3 m and 4 m (hypotenuse 5 m), and the tent is 10 m long. Find the total surface area.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Two triangular bases.
Area of one triangle = (1/2)(3)(4) = 6 sq m
Two bases = 2 × 6 = 12 sq m
Step 2: Three rectangular faces (each has width = tent length = 10 m).
3 × 10 = 30 sq m
4 × 10 = 40 sq m
5 × 10 = 50 sq m
Step 3: Total SA = 12 + 30 + 40 + 50 = 132 sq m
The total surface area of the tent is 132 square meters.

examples.problem: A square pyramid has a base with side length 6 cm and four triangular faces, each with a base of 6 cm and a slant height of 8 cm. Find the total surface area.
examples.solution:
Step 1: Base area = 6 × 6 = 36 sq cm
Step 2: Area of one triangular face = (1/2)(base)(slant height) = (1/2)(6)(8) = 24 sq cm
Four triangular faces = 4 × 24 = 96 sq cm
Step 3: Total SA = 36 + 96 = 132 sq cm
The total surface area of the pyramid is 132 square centimeters.

scaffold.title: Volume of Prisms and Cylinders — Worked Examples

examples.problem: An aquarium shaped like a rectangular prism is 20 inches long, 10 inches wide, and 12 inches tall. How much water can it hold?
examples.solution:
Formula: V = lwh
V = 20 × 10 × 12 = 2400 cubic inches
The aquarium can hold 2,400 cubic inches of water.

examples.problem: A cylindrical water bottle has a radius of 3 cm and a height of 10 cm. What is its volume?
examples.solution:
Formula: V = πr²h
V = 3.14 × 3² × 10
V = 3.14 × 9 × 10
V = 3.14 × 90 = 282.6 cm³
The water bottle holds 282.6 cubic centimeters (or 282.6 mL).

examples.problem: A triangular prism-shaped planter has a right-triangle base with legs 6 in and 8 in, and a length of 15 in. What is the volume?
examples.solution:
Step 1: Find the base area (right triangle).
B = (1/2)(6)(8) = 24 sq in
Step 2: Multiply by the height (length of the prism).
V = Bh = 24 × 15 = 360 cubic inches
The planter holds 360 cubic inches of soil.

examples.problem: A block of cheese is shaped like a rectangular prism. You slice it straight across, parallel to the front face. What shape is the cross-section?
examples.solution:
When you slice a rectangular prism parallel to one of its faces, the cross-section is the same shape as that face.
The front face is a rectangle, so the cross-section is a rectangle.

examples.problem: A can of soup is shaped like a cylinder. Describe the cross-section if you slice it (a) horizontally, parallel to the circular base, and (b) vertically, straight down through the center.
examples.solution:
(a) Horizontal slice (parallel to base): the cross-section is a circle, the same shape and size as the base.
(b) Vertical slice through the center (perpendicular to base): the cross-section is a rectangle whose width equals the diameter of the cylinder and whose height equals the height of the cylinder.

scaffold.title: Circles, Composite Figures & Surface Area Practice

problems.problem: A circular garden has a radius of 7 feet. How much fencing is needed to go around it, and how much sod is needed to cover it? (Use π ≈ 3.14)
hints: Fencing goes around the outside — that is the circumference. Use C = 2πr.
Sod covers the surface — that is the area. Use A = πr². Remember r = 7.
problems.answer: Fencing (circumference): C = 2(3.14)(7) = 43.96 ft. Sod (area): A = 3.14 × 49 = 153.86 sq ft.

problems.problem: A room is shaped like a 12 ft by 10 ft rectangle with a semicircular alcove on one of the 10-foot walls. Find the total floor area of the room.
hints: The semicircle has diameter 10 ft, so radius = 5 ft. Semicircle area = (1/2)πr².
problems.answer: Rectangle = 12 × 10 = 120 sq ft. Semicircle = (1/2)(3.14)(25) = 39.25 sq ft. Total = 120 + 39.25 = 159.25 sq ft.

problems.problem: You are wrapping a shoe box that measures 14 inches long, 10 inches wide, and 5 inches tall. How much wrapping paper do you need? (Find the surface area.)
hints: Use the rectangular prism formula: SA = 2(lw + lh + wh).
Compute each product: 14 × 10 = 140, 14 × 5 = 70, 10 × 5 = 50. Then add and multiply by 2.

problems.problem: A cylindrical water tank has a radius of 4 feet and a height of 6 feet. How many cubic feet of water can it hold?
hints: Use V = πr²h for a cylinder.
V = 3.14 × 4² × 6. Start with 4² = 16, then multiply step by step.

problems.problem: A storage container is shaped like a rectangular prism measuring 2.5 ft long, 2 ft wide, and 3 ft tall. What is its volume?
hints: For a rectangular prism, V = length × width × height.

problems.problem: A cone is sliced horizontally, parallel to its circular base. What shape is the cross-section?
hints: Think about the base of a cone — it is a circle.
A horizontal slice parallel to that circular base will produce a shape similar to the base.
problems.answer: The cross-section is a circle (smaller than the base).

problems.problem: A circular pizza has a diameter of 16 inches. What is the area of the pizza? (Use π ≈ 3.14)
A bicycle wheel has a diameter of 26 inches. How far does the bike travel in one full rotation of the wheel?

A playground is shaped like a rectangle that is 30 m long and 20 m wide, with a semicircle on each of the two shorter ends (each semicircle has a diameter of 20 m). Find the total area of the playground.
problems.answer: Rectangle = 30 × 20 = 600 sq m. Two semicircles = one full circle with r = 10: 3.14 × 100 = 314 sq m. Total = 600 + 314 = 914 sq m.

problems.problem: A cereal box is 25 cm tall, 18 cm wide, and 6 cm deep. Find its total surface area.
A cylindrical can of soup has a radius of 4 cm and a height of 12 cm. How much soup can it hold? (Find the volume.)
A triangular prism is sliced with a cut that is parallel to its triangular base. What shape is the cross-section?
A square pyramid is sliced horizontally, parallel to its square base, halfway between the base and the apex. What shape is the cross-section?
problems.answer: The cross-section is a square (smaller than the base).
